column1: According to The Infinite Dial 2022, what percentage of the US population will have "listened to a podcast in the last month?"
column5: ['Less than 42%', 'Between 42% and 44%, inclusive', 'More than 44% but less than 48%', '48% or more']
column6: ['Business', 'Technology', 'Society', 'Entertainment']
Updating based on numbers linked to by @belikewater https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1354789

Had a couple of changes of mind - was starting to think the figures could go higher than anticipated due to the increasing number of podcasts being produced this year, but on balance it seems unlikely there will be higher than 14.8% growth in monthly users given that rough estimates tend to be around 10% (details on previous forecast, under most upvoted). Anything just under 14.8% should round to 47%, i.e. still in bin3. Then considering lower figures, I think bin2 is possible, as anything around 6.5-8.5% gain would round to 44%. So the problem is partly not having much recent data to work with and partly due to the single figure rounding. I think the result will be 9-11% gain overall, so I'm reverting back to a similar split to previous.
Current rate is 41%.

Oct 29 article about 2021: "The US will also have the most monthly podcast listeners, at 117.8 million" This is very slightly above the forecast by The Infinite Dial for 2021, at 116M. Their percentages for previous years are about the same as The Infinite Dial's, but they call 117.8M 40%, whereas The Infinite Dial calls 116M 41%. They predict 42% for 2022, which would probably correspond to ~43% for The Infinite Dial, although there could be some rounding issue. Their curve looks nice and smooth and concave down, but that's because they left out all the years before 2018, which have accelerated growth. Sure, it's going to be an S curve, but have we really hit the inflection point yet? I'm not sure. One thing I like about their graph is that they give one significant figure after the decimal point. https://www.emarketer.com/content/realm-of-podcasting-us-global-leader-all-respects Hedging lower again because I'm not sure.
gjopen.com/comments/1336828
see https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1336828
After rereading comment and source links provides by @paulm I have upped the likelihood for the second bin https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1336828

Updating forecast following review of helpful discussion between @paulm and @belikewater [1] and [2]. My sense is that growth will continue but was probably stronger during 2020 due to COVID, so nudges the growth towards lower end. Spotify data in [2] seems to suggest stronger growth, so maybe I am wrong. 44-48% is now most likely, from even odds with 42-44% in my previous forecast.
@paulm, but trend lower due to data over-representing total listener count, and responders to survey being far more likely not to listen.
Thanks to @paulm for excellent analysis and updates. I do think bin 3 is likely.

I haven't got much to add to my original forecast from over two months ago: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1306211 It's not easy to find good data on this. However, Spotify is now the most popular podcasting platform globally and in the US (or soon will be). Their Q2 2021 financials show: - 2.9M podcasts in Q2, compared to 2.2M in Q1 - Q2 Monthly Active Users (MAUs) grew 22% YoY – from 299M to 365M (although that includes all streaming not just podcasts) - "The percentage of MAUs that engaged with podcast content on our platform improved modestly relative to Q1" - Their target, with a lot of uncertainty, is 400-407M MAUs at year end (globally and not specific to US) Separately there is some short term potential for churn in subscribers due to price increases/structure changes

I'm expecting an approx min of 8.5% and max of 10.5% growth for 2021, giving a total of 44-45%. I don't know whether the 41% from 2020 was rounded up or down, but the outcome looks close to the break between bins 2 and 3, and more likely to round up.
I think I've been thinking about this question wrong.
Dialed in.
I've been racking my brain for a metric when I have spent some time considering this question.
Damn. Misinterpreted the chart on page 56 on the infinite dial. Readjusting.

The percentage of the U.S. population aged 12+ that had "listened to a podcast in the last month" grew from 32% in 2019 to 37% in 2020, hitting 41% in 2021, according to The Infinite Dial 2021 (The Infinite Dial 2021, see page 56 - http://www.edisonresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/The-Infinite-Dial-2021.pdf).

Based on previous trends, the most likely outcome is 44%. But because that's on the cusp of a bin, I'll put equal weight on the next bin. I think the 4th bin is very unlikely, based on historical data; it would require a giant, unprecedented leap. I rule out the 1st bin because that would require no growth, which would also be unprecedented.
Who are these people?

Evidence shows the market is still growing, with most scope to increase monthly users in under 35 yrs old sector, over 55s, and in the Hispanic and ‘other’ ethnic groups. Limiting factors appear to be awareness; other social and entertainment networks; changing lifestyles through the pandemic; consistent historic growth... Increasing market for Google Nest, market dominance for Spotify, use of smart speakers and cars (after lockdowns), all look compatible with building regular podcast use. I think 44-46% looks very likely, +-1% possible. As results are rounded to nearest 1%, the start of bin3 is effectively 45%.

https://webby2001.medium.com/the-state-of-podcast-listening-for-2021-podcasting-finds-a-way-b485c530c55a source and text: "With 41% of the US population 12+ listening to at least one podcast in the last month, the odds are pretty good that the next time you go to a “place” and talk to “other people” (which will be later this year, I trust,) the odds are pretty good that you can talk about podcasts with the people you meet, and not only won’t they look at you funnily, they will likely have a favorite show of their own. At the end of last year, The Daily (from New York Times) was reported to have about 4 million listeners per day, greater than the number of primetime viewers to the most-watched TV news network, FOX News. "
More people will be exposed to podcasts through Facebooks’ partnership with Spotify. HT: @SE_Meyer https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1293566
holding

I actually think the second bin is more likely, given past surveys, but this forecast puts me ahead of the crowd on bins 2 and 3. I don't think bin 4 is likely because it would require an enormous jump from previous years' increases, but these are unprecedented times, so it could happen.
https://www.socialmediatoday.com/news/facebook-announces-new-integration-with-spotify-enabling-users-to-listen-to/599061/
I actually think bin 2 is more likely, based on previous data, even during 2020. But if it turns out to be bin 3, then I want to minimize my losses.

Standard media growth is projected between 2-7% annually and there is no major impact to decide whether there would be major movement beyond that (in the electronics market or elsewhere). I give a slight edge to 48+ simply because it's possible but highly unlikely, compared to the norm. A decrease is even more unlikely.
The figure is growing rapidly, recent surveys show around 30% of kids of this age have no interest in actual mainstream sports ...and this form of activity is only growing..
Review of trends and monthly podcast listeners indicate a forecast of 41%. I believe that has a credible likelihood of being understated by 1% or more but not in the upper bands of growth.

The chart shows fairly steady growth over the last few years of around 5%/year, which puts the expected value at 46%: http://www.edisonresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/The-Infinite-Dial-2021.pdf (Page 56).
44-48 larger interval.
growing activity, but hard to say > 50% of Americans will do anything the same!
Using data from presentation at http://www.edisonresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/The-Infinite-Dial-2021.pdf
Based on increased exposure and positive outlook of platforms.
rising trend, but not that new that it can rise significantly
Audiobook listening has been steady around 45% since 2015, but I think that might be a different userbase.
Article said that over 50% of Americans have listen to a podcast. http://www.edisonresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/The-Infinite-Dial-2021.pdf
In recent surveys, percentage has gone up 4-5% each year

I am less bullish on podcasts than the consensus. Many of the most popular podcasts in 2020 were about politics or the coronavirus. Cable news ratings have been tanking in the U.S as of late due to these issues becoming less captivating, and it seems reasonable to assume that the growth of podcasts will also slow in this climate.

Not sure on this one, recent growth seems to be around the 4-5% per year, but showing a steady decrease over the more recent ones. Tempted to go with 47/48 for the mid values, but the crowd seems to favor higher growth, so I will to.

Based on a model of linear growth the growth rate for podcast listenership for the last 5 years seems to be on average 4% per year. The growth in the use of smart devices and podcast awareness has surged in recent years and was likely further buoyed by the pandemic and switches to remote work. Thus, it seems very likely that podcast usership will continue to grow even as people return to normal work schedules. Therefore, It seems unlikely that podcast viewership would rise by more than 6% from 41% in 2021 and less than 4%. Thus, it seems highly likely that usership will be between 44% and 48% in 2022.
Trying my hand at a longer-term question with less data available to model relative to COVID questions. We will see how this goes.

The amount of marketing directed towards listening and induce to trying podcast is ramping up, dollars matter. The top 10 podcasts are getting as much audience ratios than top ranked live shows. So a plain average will bring the numbers in line with last 3 years averages plus a 10% for the new money in marketing specially VOX and News Corp. It should fall between 46 to 11% -47 to 59% -48 to 21% -with 49 getting 9 .
I don't think podcasts are that popular, hence less than 42 percent
First guess based on extrapolation from last years numbers in Infinite dial.
Reflecting the trend from recent years and allowing for surprises biased to higher growth than we’ve seen in the past.
Trending down this year.
Linear regression predicts 40%, exponential 41.98%... assuming follows somewhere within these trends

From that Infinite Dial report for 2021, rate in 2019 was 32%, in 2020 was 37% with the estimate (?) for 2021 being 41%. As I understand the question, we're asked what estimate it will be in the 2022 report. The increase in trend seems to be slowing - 5% rise then 4% last time around. So a 3% rise seems reasonable for 2021-22? That would take us to 44% (which makes sense when you look at how the question is framed). So I'm torn between going bigger on 42-44 or 44-48. On one hand, greater range to go for in 44-48, however, what will be the content that drives listening for the next year? I'm presuming that over the last couple of years, political podcasts would have been popular with the end of the Trump presidency. Is politics going to be 'more boring' this year meaning fewer podcasts being listened to?
More travel and other pastimes after COVID will reduce the number of people listening
14% of population not included in the 41% estimate so this year only 33% of us population listening. Despite rapid expansion unlikely to reach 42% leap in one year.
Current number is at 37%, and while that's been on a growth for some time, I expect that growth likely to slow based on people having less free time as we recover from COVID.
Has only ever gone down once (2012-2013), has increased 5 percentage points per year since 2018. COVID appears not to have had a significant impact in 2021 so I doubt it will in 2022.

I misread the chart. I thought the 41% was their forecast, but it's the value for this year. That changes things! 4% gain last year (additive), 5% the year before, 6% the year before that. A natural forecast will be a 3% increase this year, to 44%. I can't picture it being lower than 43%. But there could also be a 4% or even 5% gain, to 45% or 46%. I can't picture it going higher than that, and certainly not past 48%.

The curve upward has been so smooth, even through 2020. Their forecast seems to be 41%, but it looks like it could just as easily be 42%, 43% or even 44%. 6% was gained from 2018 to 2019, 5% from 2019 to 2020, and they anticipate a 4% gain for 2020 to 2021; but a 7% gain could be possible, too, if unlikely. But I just can't picture any radical jump to higher numbers than that. Why would they suddenly jump higher? One could argue that the pandemic has changed people's habits, but that should already be reflected in 2020's number. I don't see any driving force that would make the number jump higher than 44%.

I think I might be missing something because a lot of people have gone strongly for the above 48% but to me that seems like it would need an incredible gain. It would need to capture another 7% of population which is larger than any other recorded increase. Even looking at it from growth at it's current position it needs a 17% increase to get this and this is a trend that is going down (23% 2018-2019, 16% 2019-2020 & 11% 2020-2021) and it being a developed medium it just seems that it will become harder for it to capture more market share.

/Clubhouse (?) /exploding smart speaker ownership during work from home in 2021 /homeschooling in combination with smartphone ownership in the age group 12-34 and podcast listening behavior of this specific age group will have formed a change in permanent behavioral patterns /57% "ever listened to podcast" somewhat appears to be a limit
48% is not that high a bar in this day and age
